content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Since both of us chose 'B' in the previous round, and our goal is to maximize the total earnings across all rounds (75 rounds), it would make sense for me to try to change my strategy so that I can potentially earn more than just 40$ per round.

In this game, if I switch to 'R' when my opponent chooses 'B', I will receive 35$ in the current round, and my opponent will get 45$. If my opponent sticks with 'B' for the next round, then switching back to 'B' would result in a payoff of 40$, which is less than what I received in the previous round.

However, if my opponent also switches to 'R', I will receive 45$ in this round, and my opponent will get only 0$. If we both stick with 'R' for the next round, I would earn 45$, and my opponent would get 0$. This could potentially set us up for a cycle of earning 45$ per round.

Given that it is uncertain whether my opponent will switch strategies or not, I might consider switching to 'R' for this next round, as there is a chance that this action could lead to a higher payoff in the long run. {R}
